newsitem.title: UK: British retail sales dip in September.
newsitem.headline: British retail sales dip in September.

text.p: British retail sales dipped in September, official figures showed on Wednesday, providing evidence that while high street shops are busy there is little danger of a runaway consumer boom.
The Office for National Statistics said retail sales fell 0.3 percent in September compared with a 0.9 percent rise in August.
But longer-term measures showed consumer spending was still growing fast. The ONS said sales were 3.5 percent higher than in September a year ago.
This was a welcome boost to the ruling Conservatives who are eager to restore a strong sense of economic wellbeing before the general election, which must be held by May 1997.
Government officials pounced on the figures as evidence the consumer-led recovery is still on track.
"The fall in September sales followed a rise in August, and the two months together suggest conditions in the high (main) street are bustling," said Treasury minister Angela Knight.
A sharp fall in sales of clothing and footwear was the main culprit in dragging down overall retail activity in September.
Prices in this sector rose sharply in September and economists said retailers appeared to be finding it difficult to coax thrifty consumers into paying higher prices.
Sales of textiles, clothing and footwear fell 3.0 percent in September after jumping 2.2 percent in August. Clothing and footwear prices leapt by 5.2 percent in September.
